text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left), Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was demolished in the Summer of 1914, and was later replaced with the present Pershing Square Building. The 40th-42nd Street area acquired this designation in honor of the Commander in Chief of the American Expeditionary Force in France about this time. It was originally Fourth Avenue, a section of which was changed to Park Avenue.

About 1914

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), east side, from East 41st (right) to 42nd (left) Street's, showing the Grand Union Hotel of the 1890's. This structure was removed in the Summer of 1914. Upon this site was erected the Pershing Square Building. Note the Architects Building on the right margin; the absence of the automobile viaduct over the Avenue; and the old "El" spur on 42nd Street.

About 1914

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text:
Pershing Square (Park Ave.), west side, from East 41st (left) to 42nd (right) Streets, showing the Belmont Hotel. This building, erected about 1906, was demolished in 1931. The site, today (1937) is still vacant.

Prior to 1931.

International News Photos.
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)

text:
(1) Pershing Square, (Park Ave.) west side, from East 42nd to 41st Streets. Also shown is the Murray Hill Hotel, at No. 112 Park Ave., west side, from East 41st to 40th Streets. Building shown under demolition is the Hotel Belmont. This view is as seen from the Graybar Building and across Grand Central Station; southward. Note the raised vehicular vi- duct at this point.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing mainly the Hotel Belmont.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another view, similar to No. 2.

April 28, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Pershing Square (Park Avenue), west side, between 41st and 42nd Streets, showing outdoor café and bar.

Sept. 10, 1933
P. L. Sperr, photographer

title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street

text:
Pershing Square, at the N.E. corner of East 41st Street, as seen viewing eastward on 41st Street, from a point just west of the west side of the Square. Building shown, is the Pershing Square Building. Across its roof appears portions of the Chanin and Chrysler Buildings. Note the Vehicular viaduct at this point.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
title: Manhattan: Pershing Square - 41st Street (East)
